question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be careful to ensure the generated code is executable for display. Please help me implement the following requirement using SVG code: a visualization showing that wheat is a type of cereal plant used as food, but some people eat wheat-free whole grains.

checklist.title: Is the basic SVG structure correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the SVG code includes proper namespace declarations, viewBox settings, and responsive design considerations. Check if the SVG container is well-structured with appropriate dimensions and scaling properties. Deduct 5 points if the SVG lacks proper viewport settings, 3 points if responsive scaling is missing, and 5 points if namespace declarations are incorrect. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the wheat visualization accurately represented?
checklist.description: Review whether the SVG code visually represents wheat with botanical accuracy (wheat ears, stems, kernels). Check if the visualization correctly portrays wheat's distinctive characteristics. Award 10 points for detailed, accurate representation with proper proportions and recognizable features; 5 points if wheat is represented but lacks detail or accuracy; 0 points if wheat is unrecognizable or missing entirely.

checklist.title: Does the visualization clearly show wheat as a cereal plant?
checklist.description: Examine whether the visualization establishes wheat's classification as a cereal plant through visual elements, grouping, or labels. Check if the relationship between wheat and the broader cereal category is evident. Award 10 points if the cereal plant classification is clearly depicted through hierarchical organization, informative labeling, or comparative visualization; 5 points if the relationship is present but unclear; 0 points if this relationship is absent.

checklist.title: Does the visualization effectively show wheat-free whole grain alternatives?
checklist.description: Assess whether the visualization includes and clearly identifies wheat-free whole grain options (such as rice, oats, quinoa, millet, etc.) as alternatives. Check if these alternatives are visually distinct from wheat while still showing they belong to the broader whole grain category. Award 10 points for comprehensive, clearly labeled alternatives with visual differentiation; 5 points if alternatives are present but poorly differentiated; 0 points if wheat-free alternatives are missing.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code handles potential rendering issues across browsers, includes fallback options, and uses best practices for SVG implementation. Code with strong robustness should have comments explaining complex parts, defensive coding techniques, and browser compatibility considerations. Give 10 points for comprehensive robustness measures, 5 points for average implementation, and 0 points if robustness considerations are absent.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the visualization includes surprise features that enhance the educational experience (e.g., 1. Interactive elements showing nutritional differences 2. Morphing animations between grain types 3. Visual indicators of gluten content). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant visual elements that don't contribute to the core message 2. Unnecessary complexity in SVG path definitions 3. Decorative elements that distract from the educational content. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core visualization is obscured by redundant elements.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular organization (such as grouping related SVG elements), code reusability (through symbols, defs, or patterns), and naming conventions. Deduct 5 points if SVG elements lack meaningful IDs or classes; deduct 5 points if the code contains duplicate definitions that could be reused; deduct 5 points if there is no logical structure to element organization. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern visualization principles: 1) Harmonious color palette appropriate for food/agricultural content 2) Proper visual hierarchy with clear focal points 3) Professional typography for labels and explanatory text (readable font sizes and weights). Deduct 3 points for each cluttered area, 5 points for poor color choices that harm readability, and 5 points for inconsistent visual style. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether any included dynamic effects or interactions enhance understanding: 1) Tooltips or hover states reveal additional information 2) Animations serve educational purposes rather than being merely decorative 3) Transitions between states are intuitive and meaningful. Deduct 5 points for each interaction without clear feedback, 3 points for animations that don't contribute to understanding, and 5 points for interactive elements that aren't discoverable. The full score is 10 points.
